title: NoScript Tag XSS
description: User input is reflected inside a <noscript> tag. When JavaScript is enabled, the content of <noscript> behaves like CDATA, meaning no HTML or scripts inside it are parsed. To trigger XSS, the attacker must close the <noscript> tag and switch back into normal HTML parsing context before injecting active HTML/JavaScript.
objectives: Understand how <noscript> behaves when JavaScript is enabled.
Recognize why CDATA-like content inside <noscript> is not parsed.
Escape the noscript element to re-enter normal HTML parsing and inject JavaScript.
hints: Content inside <noscript> is treated as plain text and not parsed.
Consider what happens if the noscript tag is closed early.
Once outside the noscript tag, normal HTML parsing resumes.
body:
<article>
<script>
const q = new URLSearchParams(location.search).get('q') || '';
document.write('<noscript>' + q + '</noscript>');
</script>
</article>
